presentation.title: Platformst Du noch oder Gärtnerst Du schon? From Platforms to Protocols!
presentation.toc: Enterprise IT has an inherent tendency to build "systems". This idea of building one integrated artifact that is designed and implemented to support the business is at odds with the reality that complexity quickly gets in the way of building something that is changeable and adaptable. APIs (and microservices in particular) promise a way out of this, but only if they are used in a way that allows them to be designed and to evolve organically. It is important to understand and accept that the benefits of APIs are mostly a result of them allowing loose coupling, and an important part of modern IT architecture is to nurture and support loose coupling. Planning and providing an "API platform" often gets in the way of realizing the potential of an API-focused architecture. What is needed instead is a culture of designing and evolving an ecosystem of components that communicate through loosely coupled protocols.

Accessibility: Available to anybody
Agility: Able to respond to changes quickly
MSA is about service autonomy in service-oriented landscapes
Developer autonomy is the freedom to choose the best tools for the job
Operations autonomy means that every service is operated in standalone way
MSA is also about effectiveness in an autonomy-focused service-oriented landscapes
Rapid provisioning means that getting started is an easy task
Basic monitoring establishes visibility into service operations
Rapid deployment increases the velocity of available service landscape
Platforms provide support but also create constraints
Support in the form of a foundation and shared services/infrastructure
Constraints in the form of removing certain design options
Balancing support and constraints is not always done explicitly
Adding features is more immediately visible than removing options
Microservices for the first time in enterprise IT take a step back
Remove constraints to foster innovation and give teams more solution options
Add support mostly in an attempt to make the platform economically viable
Platforms often are conceived as being actual infrastructure
Centralized components that provide capabilities and host services
They become convenient components where every infrastructure problem is solved
Is the ESB platform pattern an inescapable vicious circle?
What if every capability had to be an API-driven service itself?
What if the platform would focus on defining/providing APIs?
A set of shared principles, protocols, and practices
Principles govern the general architectural style (REST)
Protocols define the way in which components interact
Practices are design patterns for when/how to use certain protocols
The Web is and always has been about microservices
Encapsulation and strict API-only interactions
Services can start/evolve/succeed/fail/disappear entirely on their own
Discovery is just another service
Description is part of a service itself and as much as necessary
Shared nothing architecture with no single point of contention
Avoid the anti-pattern of centralized implementation
Do not force APIs top be provided in one way/place
Do not force APIs top be consumed in one way/place
Any constraints should be by policy only
Platforms/landscapes should follow the principles/protocols/practices (P3) pattern
